title: Friday, 15th February 2019

So .......... what on earth happened here?

FATDAZ Morning all another lovely day in London

BE11:10am

It is understood the company only discovered that what it had said in the annual report was wrong on Tuesday, the same day it issued a profit warning in its annual results that sent its shares down 31 per cent and sparked questions from analysts about the timings of its disclosures.

FJ Gambling addicts don't mind. It's albout a dream
nightingale20201 morning all

That's what's understood, is it? Great. Ignorance as to how your business generates a third of its income is the excuse? Great stuff.

FATDAZ news releases sorry
nightingale20201 Bryce....any chance to go through SLA, please...thanks
red fwiw in the city it has always been known how plus500 and in fact other similar brokers earn their money. as i said before, if u didn't the swiss incident should have cleared that up for you.

red BE, there are much greater lies than have happened in the city and are happening right now
11:15 am

Anyway, if you want some grey on Plus you can have Peel Hunt.

BE11:16am

Fundamentally the shape of Plus500’s earnings has changed,
with its increased disclosure highlighting both the positive and
negative impact from client P&L. After reviewing our model, we
downgrade the underlying forecasts by 28% as we remove client
P&L and show a ‘cleaner’ result. Positively, Plus is actively
pursuing a retention policy and continues to invest to acquire
new clients. On rebased forecasts we move our target price to
1,300p (9.8x 19E PER) from 1,650p and retain our Add given
that earnings quality has improved with enhanced disclosure,
while accepting that it will take time to rebuild confidence.

PBateman Morning
red FCA job is to go after minor incident retail investors and let the big boys get on with it. thats the way of the world.
BE11:16am

Earnings quality. Plus 500’s results led to a 34% fall in the share price as increased
disclosure highlighted the nature of the group’s earnings. The most significant point
was the scale and impact of client losses: in 2018 this contributed 34%, or $172m,
to PBT. This is in contrast to 2017, when client gains ($103m) reduced PBT by
29%. Lower leverage rules should significantly reduce the contribution of client
P&L given reduced client exposures, with most (97%) revenue coming from spread
and financing directly related to client trading activity. The current quarterly runrate
based on Q4 2018 spread and financing revenue is $99m.
Other points. The analyst meeting highlighted:
 New leverage rules led to a fall in quarterly spread & financing income (-27%
YoY), which had been masked by a high level of client losses in Q4.
 c75% of costs are variable, but marketing spend will be maintained as the
return remains highly attractive (for example, five-year ROI from marketing
investment into revenue sits at 117%).
 Client retention is improving, with the rate increasing to 54% in 2018 from
38% in 2016, and is expected to continue to rise as Plus focuses on retention
initiatives (such as targeting existing clients with customised content in their
native language) and could also see a positive effect from leverage rules as
clients lose smaller sums and are thus likely to trade for longer.
Changes to forecasts. Below we highlight our changes to forecasts. The
downgrades are a result of us rebasing revenue to spread and financing income
(using the current run-rate) and growing this by 15% with client losses
contributing an additional 3% to revenue. We increase costs as marketing
increases and the group pursues growth as well as investing for retention.

PBateman Slaberdeen would be cool
11:16 am
BE11:16am

(@red: that is also, with respect, a shite argument.)

The core argument is that Drax has massively overpaid for the Iberdrola UK generation fleet.

red they are generally serial losers, noobs, dreamers, hopers. all looking to make a quick buck. and the irony of it all is plus500 doesnt and has no need to manipulate their platform to get their clients to lose money as they do it all by themselves.
BE11:18am

In particular the Cruachan pumped-storage hydro electric power station up north, which is designed to meet peak-power demands by holding water in tanks and firing it at the turbines when needed.

Upaswellasdown morning all. Plus500 is another one of those names that is long-term uninvestible because it makes money in ways its customers don't want / like
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Thanks BE for Drax. ;)
BE11:19am

Which is useful, arguably, as the world moves increasingly to solar and wind and whatnot.

Upaswellasdown @BE, do you have an exception to the profanity filter?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Because you can't turn the sun on when there's a power surge in the middle of X Factor or whatever.

BE11:20am

Except it's not panning out like that.

BE11:20am

The spread between peak and off peak power prices has been narrowing since 2012.

urgeview red, whereas you are a genius, with all your obvious statements of fact
11:21 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

(@ROTR: don't let it go Lord of the Flies over there please.)

BE11:22am

And any bet on the spread widening ignores batteries and interconnects playing a bigger role in terms of load management in the future.

JulioIgelsias morning
11:22 am
BE11:22am

We believe the purchase of IBE generation assets is value destructive, to the tune of c.£140m. Despite a +20% in UK generation from intermittent renewable sources, similar pump storage assets have actually seen a reduction to peak / off peak spreads from c.£12/MWh to £7/MWh. This together with an expected 10x increase in UK’s utility scale battery storage capacity to 2025, and a 3x increase in UK’s interconnection capacity to 2022, we see little reason to be bullish on the outlook for pump storage assets.

red @Upaswellasdownthe change came when the news regs came in last summer. that was a warning which some along with many large shareholders headed. these days the best case for them is to continue to draw in clients and the shares will reach a trough, trading at a heavy continued discount to sector, but while they continue to make money and operate a policy to pay out a large amount of profits, the shares will be supported at some stage. i suggested earlier in the week below 10 quid and we are here. levels around 700-750 may be supportive.
BE11:23am

Add to that you have commodity prices heading lower.

BE11:23am

The correlation between Drax share price and commodity prices appears to be broken. Since January, Drax shares are +10% vs -10% of UK power and gas. In our view, this decoupling is unjustified and we see significant downside risk to Drax’s share price.

Early Doors Morning, sorry I'm late
11:23 am
BE11:23am

And the suspension of the EU capacity market.

BE11:23am

Capacity payment will contribute to c.15% of Drax’s EBITDA (normalized for FY19-21). While our working assumption is that the capacity market resumes in FY20 with no major changes to the structure of the auction process thereafter, there is no guarantee that this would be the outcome. Furthermore, we see Ofgem’s strategic review of the microbusiness retail market to increase level of competition and/or intervention. Drax shares are currently priced as if neither such risks exist.

Early Doors Ironic I know haha
red @urgeviewno genius. i am just usually right. by lucky or judgement, it doent matter. its the fact that matters in order to make a success of investing/trading.
BE11:24am

So, forecasts dumped.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We update our earning and PT to reflect the latest commodity prices and acquisition of IBE generation assets. Our EBITDA is -1% to +49%, while our EPS is +70% to -46% over 2018-20E. 12m PT now at 320p.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

FTSE 100/All Share/Europe/Stoxx Europe 600 – there should be no
impact as FTSE and Stoxx considered MUFJ holdings already to be part
of free float and, hence, there will be no increase in free float.
 MSCI, is currently using a 90% free float factor for SLA. It is not clear
whether MSCI considered MUFG’s holding as strategic or free float. If
MSCI considered MUFG holdings as strategic, then MSCI is likely to
increase free float factor intra-quarter, exp. early next week. The
estimated passive demand could be 10.5mn shares. If MSCI considered
MUFG holdings as non-strategic, then there will be no passive impact.

Bluesky21 Not sure why they bothered. The could just have taken some index funds, subtract a chunk of money each year, and delivered the same returns :)
red think they will need fresh numbers to turn things around. might be 750. maybe even around 400p. but somewhere in there entirely poss.
DJ @red, hindsight bias is always with me
JulioIgelsias i like the thought of a passive impact! bit of an oxymoron no?
BE11:34am

And I've run out of things to say there. If I think of anything I'll come back to it.

red @DJcant fret about what you missed out on. there are plenty of ops everyday, just need to prepare in advance for them.
BE11:35am

(@JulioIgelsias: yes indeed, it's because people fear the word "effect" so use impact as a synonym.)

11:35 am
undefined

Scout24 mentioned on the right.

Having been for sale for a wee while, Hellman & Friedman (H&F) / Blackstone come in at €46 per share.

red @JulioIgelsiasi have sla as part of a 25 strong yield portfolio set up in dec. its been a real dog even since then but overall up 10%ytd. indicates the benefits of diversification.
11:36 am
BE11:36am

or €5.7bn, which gets support from the board.

BE11:37am

We -- as in the FT, not me personally -- had reported PE interest in Scout back in December. Silver Lake, H&F and Blackstone all namechecked.

BE11:38am

Then we had a public knockback a month ago from H&F / Blackstone at €43.50 per share, and a flip of the advisors from defence to sale.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

There remains the possibility of a counter, but it's not that obvious given the rather transparent process up to this point.

VV75 anything on Ubisoft perhaps, rather a peculiar move after opening?
BE11:40am

H&F / Blackstone are of course Scout's former owners and would be thought to have a clearer view than most other potential buyers on the Bestellerpinzip regulation stuff.

BE11:41am

There's a monster note from Olivetree on this. I'll skip to the conclusion.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Views on the pending Bestellerprinzip regulation are divergent and without draft legislation, which is expected imminently, there is considerable uncertainty around the issue. Given that the impact of the regulatory change is difficult to model the debate around its impacts will continue post publication of the draft legislation. The Bestellerprinzip outcome could add meaningful optionality to this trade. Locals have this morning concurred that the situation is extremely interesting given the jurisdiction and Scout’s situation.

BE11:42am

Whilst the minimum acceptance condition is at 50% +1 share, the language available to use at present does not rule out squeeze out/domination proceedings to our knowledge. The market will view this as a very interesting prospect with respect to the back end trade.

BE11:43am

And Liberum, for a slightly less arb-y take.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We see the Private Equity bid as on the low side, representing just under 17x adjusted FY19E EBITDA vs our €56 Target Price, which would have represented just under 20x EBITDA, a multiple that is only slightly above the c. 19x that PE firm Silver Lake paid for ZPG.

To put in context, Scout24 is the market leader in the German property classifieds business, as well as the #1 in automotive classifieds in Italy, Benelux and Austria, #2 in Germany as well as having a significant minority stake in the #1 player in Spain. ZPG, on the other hand, was a distant #2 in the UK property classifieds business with a significant chunk of its revenues from more volatile Price Comparison Website (PCW) revenues

BE11:43am

The question now is whether other bidders emerge. We don't think these will necessarily come from private equity (who may be cautious about picking a fight with two big peers). A more likely scenario is a bid (either individual or joint) from other classified industry players such as Axel Springer (NR), Schibsted (NR) or Naspers (NR) who would want all or parts of Scout's business (although Axel Springer would not be able to hold the German property classifieds business, and Schibsted would have probably have to sell the stake in the Spanish automotive classifieds business).

undefined

Anyway, spin back to Ubisoft.

pancakes or waffles in the sense that, playing it 15 mins or 4 hours makes no diff in terms of progress in terms of purely theoretical terms
BE11:53am

Q3's fine. Guidance doesn't change.

BE11:53am

Goldman incoming.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

UBI’s F3Q19 bookings of €606 mn (v. guidance of €600 mn) slightly missed consensus (FactSet) of €610 mn. Ubisoft reiterated its F2019 guidance including for PRI. F3Q19 PRI growth of 27% yoy beat our estimate and likely benefited from For Honor, Rainbow Six Siege, and Assassin’s Creed Odyssey. That said, the implied F4Q19 PRI growth of 4% marks a meaningful qoq slowdown. This is partly due to difficult year-ago comps from Ghost Recon Wildlands and Rainbow Six Siege’s Outbreak event, though UBI also highlighted the potential impact from competitive new game launches for Rainbow Six Siege. Assassin’s Creed Odyssey engagement was better than UBI’s expectations, reaffirming its view that the introduction of RPG elements can help drive PRI

JulioIgelsias @upaswellasdownCouldn't agree more. The issue will be for companies where that lease is long and unbreakable and potentially backed by cashflows which wont exist (or be a lot lower)
BE11:53am

F3Q19 bookings of €606 mn beat our estimate of €558 mn, but slightly missed consensus (FactSet) of €610 mn (v. guidance of €600 mn). Mobile and PC were particularly strong, with mobile bookings growth of over 100% yoy driven by its licensing business in Asia, 1492 acquisition, South Park, and Assassin’s Creed Rebellion.

red @pancakes or wafflesi see. so its not level based but vs other folks right?
BE11:54am

Imagine voluntarily playing a South Park game. What goes wrong in a person's life for them to reach that point?

tariffguy re. irn bru. It's not the diet version, it's the new 'sugar tax' version.
wayneJ Yep - there was a time when the investment community was only interested in 'mobile gaming'. Quite good fund to see 50 yr fund managers pretending to know the latest trends......(oh heck, just realised how old I am - I remember the original Elite....)
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Player recurring investment (PRI) beats, but expected to slow in F4Q19. F3Q19 PRI of €182 mn beat our estimate of €160 mn and grew 27% yoy. That said, UBI reaffirmed its expectation of 30% of bookings from PRI (implied €615 mn on €2.05 bn of full-year bookings guidance), implying 4% yoy PRI growth in F4Q19. PRI growth is expected to slow in F4Q as difficult year-ago comps from Rainbow Six Siege’s Outbreak event, competition from other first-person shooters, and difficult comps from Ghost Recon Wildlands more than offset the benefit from Far Cry 5, Far Cry New Dawn, and The Division 2. Further, we estimate that MAUs declined yoy in F3Q19 assuming that MAUs are equal weighted by quarter and based on UBI’s commentary that MAUs increased by 17% yoy in the 9-months year-to-date through F3Q19 (v. +29% yoy in the 6 months to date through F1H19).

BE11:54am

Assassin’s Creed Odyssey engagement better-than-expected, proving the benefit of RPG-elements on PRI. Assassin’s Creed Odyssey is realizing strong engagement with longer playtimes, conversion rates, completion rates, and in-game metrics relative to Origins. Odyssey should have a longer life than Origins; accordingly, Ubisoft is deferring Odyssey’s season pass revenue over a longer period of time. Although Ubisoft would not comment on Odyssey’s unit performance relative to Origins, it stated that Odyssey sell-in exceeded its expectation in what was a competitive launch period.
Ubisoft reiterated key FY19 targets including (1) 19 mn AAA units; (2) €2.05 bn in net bookings; (3) €440 mn in EBIT; (4) FCF of €300 mn; and (5) 30% of bookings from PRI.

wayneJ (Re-edit: Imagine voluntarily reading FTML. What goes wrong in a person's life for them to reach that point? :-) )
BE11:55am

And Exane.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

A reassuring release given peers’ recent publications
Given the negative investor sentiment ahead of the release, we think the Q3 18/19 performance
(in line) and FY guidance reiteration should be sufficient to ease investors’ concern. Following
recent stock weakness relative to peers, Ubisoft is now trading on a c.20% discount to peers on
EV/EBIT. Even after normalizing EA’s multiples (currently inflated by Apex success), Ubisoft would
still trade on a discount to peers. This level heavily underestimates Ubisoft’s business
fundamentals, top-line growth profile and medium-term catch up opportunity on margin, in our
view. Outperform reiterated with EUR103 TP.
Solid performance in Q3 18/19 given difficult comp base and competition
Ubisoft’s Q3 18/19 net bookings were down 16% YoY at EUR606m (+1% vs guidance, in line with
Bloomberg consensus). Net bookings were 5% below our estimate due to a weaker than expected
performance of “Starlink Battle for Atlas” and a lower average ASP for “AC Odyssey”. The YoY
decline was mainly due to the phasing of the AC Odyssey release, a less supportive casual game
pipeline and a tough competitive environment. Digital net bookings remained robust (+15.5% YoY),
supported mostly by PRI growth (+26%), while digital distribution was up +7%.
FY guidance reiterated, we still see some upside on it
Ubisoft reiterated its FY guidance (net bookings EUR2.05bn, Adj. EBIT EUR440m), which implies
c.EUR700m net bookings in Q4 18/19 (c.+30% YoY). Given the solid pipeline (The Division 2,
Far Cry New Dawn), we feel comfortable with the Q4 guidance and actually expect c.EUR730m
net bookings. Our revised estimate remains above the FY EBIT guidance (EUR468m).
Estimates cut by 2%, we remain above guidance and consensus post update
The cuts mostly reflect a lower ASP for AC Odyssey (EUR32 vs EUR35) and lower units for
“Starlink Battle for Atlas” (1m vs 2m expected). We have also slightly lowered our PRI for 2018/19
given a challenging comp base in Q4 18/19.

pancakes or waffles not in the classical sense. it is basically a massive battle royale format where the last player standing wins. however, it is free to play and u (mostly) pay if u want cosmetic/aesthetic upgrades (at least thats what i understand). so it does not require much commitment, has a ton of replayable value

What are we missing?

FATDAZ @red agreed but then many people would probably ask me why I get excited about macro data and charts etc

(@wayneJ: haven't got to Tesco yet this morning, but clearly IFRS16 is going to mean the tide going out on a lot of sale-and-leasebacks.)

FATDAZ @red :)
11:59 am
BE11:59am

(It's a theme we should deffo look at more.)

wayneJ @BE - I think the link was to a report by an analyst who was at the time based in HK. Sorry can't remember more but it was somewhere in FTAV.
